s.text: In its Thursday edition, the Herald led with a revelation that Australian military officers working as U.N. arms inspectors in Baghdad had placed and operated spying devices that were later used by the U.S. to select targets for Operation Desert Fox.

In its Thursday edition, the Herald led with a revelation that Australian military officers working as U.N. arms inspectors in Baghdad had placed and operated spying devices that were later used by the U.S. to select targets for Operation Desert Fox.

In its Thursday edition, the Herald led with a revelation that Australian military officers working as U.N. arms inspectors in Baghdad had placed and operated spying devices that were later used by the U.S. to select targets for Operation Desert Fox.

The Russian ambassador to the United Nations Sergei Lavrov had described Butler's report to the Security Council, used by the U.S. and British governments to justify the bombing of Iraq last month, as "not professional," "biased," and "provocative," the paper said.

The Russian ambassador to the United Nations Sergei Lavrov had described Butler's report to the Security Council, used by the U.S. and British governments to justify the bombing of Iraq last month, as "not professional," "biased," and "provocative," the paper said.

It added that the pope must also have been saddened not only by "Sexgate" but also by Clinton's attacks on Sudan, Afghanistan, and Iraq, since "in 1993, at the time of their first meeting in Denver, he probably saw in the young Clinton, so socially committed, a potential partner in the reconstruction of a just and peaceful world after a century of hot and cold wars."
